author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: In New York mayor’s first week, battling the pandemic and then a devastating fire.
description: Before he took office as mayor of New York City, Eric Adams repeatedly said that his top priority was to serve as the city’s cheerleader and promote its recovery.
content: Before he took office as mayor of New York City, Eric Adams repeatedly said that his top priority was to serve as the city’s cheerleader and promote its recovery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: South Indian Food That Goes Back to Its Roots, at Semma
description: The latest restaurant from the creators of Dhamaka and Adda finds excitement in deep cuts from Tamil Nadu and other states.
content: The servers at Semma walk around in long-sleeve black T-shirts printed with a white logo that says Unapologetic Indian. This is a reference to Unapologetic Foods, the company that runs Semma along with Dhamaka and Adda Indian Canteen. It’s also the group’s slogan, a vow to offer cuisine that pulls no punches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson and Victor Mather
title: N.F.L. Coach Firings Follow Regular Season’s End
description: The Bears, Vikings and Broncos all fired their coaches after losing seasons and prepared to remake their franchises. In a surprising move, so did the Dolphins, who finished with a winning record.
content: The Monday after the N.F.L. regular season is a perilous day to be a head coach. This year, Brian Flores, Matt Nagy and Mike Zimmer all found themselves out of a job, joining Vic Fangio of the Broncos, who was dismissed a day before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Fire Screens
description: Because if you’re lucky enough to have a fireplace, it deserves a good fire screen.
content: If you have a wood-burning fireplace, a functional fireplace screen is essential to keep the room from being showered with burning embers. But it also has an aesthetic role to play, as it will be front and center during fireside gatherings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Virshup
title: The World Has Changed. So Has ‘52 Places.’
description: Our annual list of destinations to visit this year looks at spots where visitors can be part of the solution to problems like overtourism and climate change.
content: This year, the second in a row, the Times Travel desk faced the challenge of creating one of our signature pieces of journalism, the annual “52 Places” list, in a world turned upside down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Ex-Oklahoma Officer Is Sentenced in Killing of Daughter’s Boyfriend
description: Shannon Kepler, who had served as a police officer in Tulsa for 24 years, was tried five times before a federal jury found him guilty of the 2014 murder of Jeremey Lake, 19.
content: A former police officer in Tulsa, Okla., was sentenced on Friday to 25 years in prison for the 2014 killing of his daughter’s boyfriend after a jury found him guilty of second-degree murder in his fifth trial in the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Apply to The New York Times Diverse Crossword Constructor Fellowship
description: The fellowship will provide mentorship for new constructors who are women, people of color or part of the L.G.B.T.Q. community.
content: We are excited to announce the first-ever New York Times Diverse Crossword Constructor Fellowship, which will begin accepting applications on Feb. 7. This fellowship is to provide mentorship and support for constructors from underrepresented groups, including women, people of color and the L.G.B.T.Q. community. We want our puzzles to reflect the reality of all Americans, which means we want to publish work that reflects a diverse range of cultural reference points, language usage and communities. This fellowship is for constructors who have not yet been published by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Don Maynard, Hall of Fame Receiver for Champion Jets, Dies at 86
description: He teamed with the quarterback Joe Namath in a passing attack that took New York to an upset victory in Super Bowl III against the powerful Colts.
content: Don Maynard, the Hall of Fame wide receiver who teamed with Joe Namath in the passing attack that propelled the Jets to their storied 1969 upset victory in the Super Bowl, died on Monday at an assisted living facility in Ruidoso, N.M. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Jesse Watters Is Promoted to an Evening Slot on Fox News
description: Mr. Watters, a sardonic conservative with a pro-Trump bent, will take over the 7 p.m. hour.
content: Twenty years ago, a recent college graduate named Jesse Watters joined Fox News as a production assistant. He finagled his way into an on-camera gig as a sidekick to Bill O’Reilly, before expanding his ambush-style man-on-the-street interviews into a weekend program and a role as co-host of the talk show “The Five.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Raiders Use 17th Game (and Then Some) to Slide Into Postseason
description: In an odd game in which a tie could have sent both teams to the playoffs, the Raiders outlasted the Chargers in overtime, eliminating their division rival.
content: LAS VEGAS — The running joke on social media last week was that if the circumstances called for it, the Raiders and the Chargers should make a pact.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Morris
title: At-Home Coronavirus Tests Are Inaccessible to Blind People
description: With visual cues and complex steps, at-home coronavirus tests are often inaccessible to blind people. But some low- and high-tech workarounds could help.
content: Christy Smith has never been tested for the coronavirus. As a blind person, she can’t drive to testing sites near her home in St. Louis, and they are too far away for her to walk. Alternative options — public transportation, ride share apps or having a friend drive her to a test site — would put others at risk for exposure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Davey Alba
title: Covid Test Misinformation Spikes Along With Spread of Omicron
description: The added demand for testing and the higher prevalence of breakthrough cases have created an “opportune moment” to exploit.
content: On Dec. 29, The Gateway Pundit, a far-right website that often spreads conspiracy theories, published an article falsely implying that the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention had withdrawn authorization of all P.C.R. tests for detecting Covid-19. The article collected 22,000 likes, comments and shares on Facebook and Twitter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Ailey’ and ‘Somebody Somewhere’
description: PBS’s “American Masters” airs a documentary on the choreographer Alvin Ailey. And a bittersweet comedy series debuts on HBO.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Jan. 10-16. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: The Big Cheeses From the Vineyard
description: Prufrock, a washed-rind cheese from Grey Barn on Martha’s Vineyard, took honors at the recent World Cheese Awards.
content: A satiny washed-rind beauty named Prufrock was the first cheese made at the Grey Barn, a farm and dairy on Martha’s Vineyard, which was established in 2009 and began selling the cheese in 2012. The tidy eight-ounce square, encased in an edible orange-hued rind, has collected awards over the years, and in the 2021 World Cheese Awards, Prufrock was one of six cheeses from five countries to win gold in the general washed-rind category. It also won recognition at the first New York International Cheese competition, held last summer. The cheese, made from organic milk, has alluring washed rind funkiness, with a scent of dried wildflowers and a yeasty, briny tang on the palate. Eric and Molly Glasgow, the farm’s owners, decided to go poetic with the name instead of giving it a local tie-in. They’ve continued in that vein with most of their other cheeses, including Banneker, their newest, a Cheddar they started making during the pandemic and only sell locally. It’s named for Benjamin Banneker, an 18th century African American mathematician and astronomer and the subject of a poem by Rita Dove.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Can Free Trade Work for Everyone?
description: A prominent Republican economist admits that open markets have hurt some people. But tariffs, he says, aren’t the answer.
content: Glenn Hubbard tried to dissuade President George W. Bush from putting tariffs on imported steel. As chairman of Bush’s Council of Economic Advisers, he told the president in 2001 that the harm from tariffs suffered by consumers of steel would vastly outweigh the benefits to steel makers. He argued that trying to preserve steel jobs through tariffs would be like trying to save farm jobs in the early 20th century, when farms became more productive and people went to work in factories instead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Woo
title: What It Was Like on the Elizabeth Holmes Jury for 18 Weeks
description: Away from the media frenzy, jurors dealt with the trial’s disruption to their lives and had little idea of the case’s implications.
content: SAN JOSE, Calif. — If you wondered what it was like to serve as a juror in Silicon Valley’s trial of the decade, Susanna Stefanek can tell you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Maple Syrup With a Hint of Brooklyn Bourbon
description: Fort Hamilton Brooklyn Barrel-Aged Maple Syrup gets its flavor from a stint in a recycled liquor barrel in Industry City.
content: Fort Hamilton Distillery, a five-year-old enterprise in Industry City, Brooklyn, named for the 19th century military installation guarding the east side of the Narrows in New York Harbor (Fort Wadsworth on Staten Island faces it to the west), specializes in rye whiskies, and also makes bourbon. To this portfolio it has just added a bourbon barrel-aged maple syrup. The organic syrup, from the Catskills, is given 100 days in the charred white oak barrels used to age its whiskies. The deep amber syrup is thick and scented of earth and smoke, elements that carry into its rich flavor. Alex Clark — who founded the distillery with his wife, Amy Grindeland — is making it as a way to further the life of the bourbon barrels, since according to federal standards, the whiskey must be aged in new barrels. Mr. Clark uses the syrup in an old-fashioned. I like it over cornbread and buckwheat pancakes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Shipstead
title: The Daughter of a Revolutionary Becomes a Wedding Planner. Drama Ensues.
description: In Xochitl Gonzalez’s debut novel, “Olga Dies Dreaming,” a Puerto Rican family reckons with abandonment, secrets and vastly different priorities.
content: OLGA DIES DREAMINGBy Xochitl Gonzalez
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung and Michael Gold
title: What We Know About the Bronx Apartment Building Fire
description: The blaze began just before 11 a.m. on Sunday in a building on East 181st Street. Eight children were killed.
content: On Sunday, a five-alarm fire ignited in a 19-story Bronx apartment building, filling the high-rise with thick plumes of smoke that trapped tenants in stairwells and filled their lungs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: A large African community found a home in the Bronx apartment building.
description: Many residents of the high-rise sought it out for its close-knit feel and proximity to area mosques.
content: The high-rise in the Bronx where 17 people died in a fire on Sunday was home to many African immigrants who chose their apartments for the close-knit community and proximity to local mosques.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: A Naturalist Stumbled on an Ichthyosaur Skeleton, the Largest in U.K. History
description: The fossilized remains of the marine reptile, often referred to as a “sea dragon” and believed to be 180 million years old, were discovered at a nature reserve.
content: At the bottom of a lagoon at a nature reserve in England, a secret lay dormant for millenniums, hidden by mud, water and ice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Famed White Cliffs of Sicily Are Defaced in an Act of Vandalism
description: Vandals stained a cliff formation known as the Staircase of the Turks with red splotches over the weekend. Residents of a nearby town banded together for a successful cleanup.
content: ROME — Saturday was a bad news, good news sort of day for Sabrina Lattuca, the mayor of Realmonte, a small town on the western coast of Sicily.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘After 110 Years, an Overdue Book Is Returned to a Library in Idaho’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about the journey of a book that was checked out in 1911 and not returned until 2021. Then, they will discuss the importance of libraries and learn about how they are cataloged.
content: Featured Article: “After 110 Years, an Overdue Book Is Returned to a Library in Idaho” by Alyssa Lukpat
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Russian Troops Will Stay to Finish Job in Kazakhstan, Putin Says
description: Blaming “internal and external forces” for the unrest in the resource-rich Central Asian country, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia set no deadline for the withdrawal of the forces his country sent there.
content: MOSCOW —  President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said on Monday that recent unrest in Kazakhstan had been caused by “destructive internal and external forces” and that more than 2,000 troops his country had sent as “peacekeepers” would leave only once their mission was complete.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: Free At-Home Tests
description: And what else is new in testing.
content: The Biden administration today released the details of its plan to allow Americans to be reimbursed for at-home virus tests through private insurance. Here’s what you need to know:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: Giants G.M. Dave Gettleman to Retire; Coach’s Fate Uncertain
description: In a little over four years as the Giants general manager, Gettleman failed to hire a successful head coach. His replacement may soon get the chance.
content: The Giants have had only five general managers since 1974, a spell of stability and patience illustrated by the four Super Bowl trophies on display at their headquarters in East Rutherford, N.J. But it has been 10 years since their last title — five since their last playoff appearance — and that sliver of time might as well be an epoch in their universe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt
title: The Biden administration gave a preview of how it would punish Russia if it invaded Ukraine.
description: Such moves are rarely telegraphed in advance, but advisers say they are hoping to influence the decisions of Russia’s leader, Vladimir V. Putin.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration and its allies are assembling a punishing set of financial, technology and military sanctions against Russia that they say would go into effect within hours of an invasion of Ukraine, hoping to make clear to President Vladimir V. Putin the high cost he would pay if he sends troops across the border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: Our Kids Are Behind in School. Here’s How to Help Them.
description: Will Covid closures lead to an overhaul of public school systems?
content: In the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina, which struck in August 2005, many New Orleans public schools were closed for several months. The median amount of time missed by students who resumed their education in Louisiana was about five weeks. When schools began reopening in 2006, teachers and administrators reported that the majority of kids were significantly behind in learning, most notably in math.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: In U.S.-Russia Talks, How Far Can Putin Turn Back the Clock?
description: The Cold War echoes of the negotiations unfolding this week in a series of meetings between Russia and the West are a reminder that there is nothing permanent about Europe’s security arrangements.
content: WASHINGTON — To the Biden administration, the direct talks that began in earnest on Monday in Geneva are about defusing the chances of a major war in Europe — potentially ignited by a Russian invasion of Ukraine — and upholding the principle that nations cannot redraw international borders by force.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: Cookies? Chips? Pizza? Here’s How to Own Your Cravings
description: For the Eat Well Challenge, mindfulness techniques like “urge surfing” can help curb overeating without banning favorite foods.
content: Food cravings are a normal part of the human experience; studies show that more than 90 percent of people have them. (In fact, who are those unicorns who’ve never had cravings?)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: U.S. and Russia Will Discuss European Security, but Without Europeans
description: The coming talks in Geneva are bilateral, reviving old fears that the two Cold War powers will forge a deal on their own.
content: BRUSSELS — The European Union’s foreign policy chief, Josep Borrell Fontelles, visited Ukrainian troops in the contested Donbas region last Wednesday, staring through a fence at the positions of Russian-backed separatists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor and Claire Fahy
title: Crashed Pilot Is Pulled to Safety Seconds Before Train Plows Through
description: Los Angeles police officers pulled the pilot of a small plane away from the tracks moments before a train smashed into it at high speed.
content: With dramatic timing seen frequently in the movies but rarely with an actual life on the line, rescuers pulled a pilot from the wreckage of his plane’s crash landing just seconds before a train smashed into it in Los Angeles on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: A Devastating Fire, Apparently Caused by a Space Heater
description: At least 19 people, including nine children, died. Mayor Eric Adams called the numbers “horrific.”
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll check the latest on the devastating fire in the Bronx. We’ll look at Mayor Eric Adams’s first week, and we’ll look at what’s happening with redistricting, the process of redrawing the maps for the state’s legislative and congressional districts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer
title: U.S. Greenhouse Gas Emissions Bounced Back Sharply in 2021
description: Emissions rose 6 percent last year after a record 10 percent decline in 2020, fueled by a rise in coal power and truck traffic as the U.S. economy rebounded from the pandemic.
content: WASHINGTON — America’s greenhouse gas emissions from energy and industry rose 6.2 percent in 2021 as the economy began recovering from pandemic lows and the nation’s coal plants roared back to life, according to a preliminary estimate published Monday by the Rhodium Group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: 2021 Was Earth’s Fifth-Hottest Year, Scientists Say
description: The finding, by European researchers, fits a clear warming trend: The seven hottest years on record have been the past seven.
content: Last year was Earth’s fifth hottest on record, European scientists announced on Monday. But the fact that the worldwide average temperature didn’t beat the record is hardly reason to stop worrying about global warming’s grip on the planet, they said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Moya Lothian-McLean
title: Boris Johnson Is Revealing Who He Really Is
description: A raft of repressive legislation shows the prime minister’s true colors.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain, bruised by scandal and faced with an alarming rise in coronavirus cases, is refusing to change course. “We have a chance,” he bullishly proclaimed on Jan. 4, “to ride out this Omicron wave without shutting down our country once again.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: 20 Years Later, the Story Behind the Guantánamo Photo That Won’t Go Away
description: On Jan. 11, 2002, a sailor photographed 20 men in orange uniforms and on their knees, capturing one of the most damning post-9/11 images of U.S. detention policy.
content: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — Four months to the day after the Sept. 11 attacks, a photographer hoisted a camera above shiny new razor wire and took a picture of 20 prisoners on their knees in orange uniforms, manacled, masked and heads bowed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A New Line of Cookware Designed With Thomas Keller
description: Hestan’s Thomas Keller Insignia line was crafted with input from the chef of French Laundry.
content: The cookware from the California company Hestan is made in Italy and designed for the professional and the amateur. The professional side just received an upgrade with a new line designed with input from the chef Thomas Keller. He insisted on pans that were more generous in circumference to suit larger burners in restaurant kitchens (and to accommodate the professional-style ranges that serious home cooks often buy). And he has also put his stamp on some shapes like a wide, two-handled rondeau and a saucier, new to Hestan’s inventory. The pans are stainless steel with an aluminum core, have handles designed to stay cool, are made with flush rivets on the inside for better cleaning and have two universal lids. Some come with nonstick finishes, though none have the company’s excellent Titanium finish that’s used in a different series of pans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wilson and Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: ‘We Were Just Trying to Breathe’: Frantic Rush to Escape the Smoke
description: Residents who survived the Bronx inferno on Sunday described a quiet morning that suddenly was overtaken by terror and tragedy.
content: It started as a lazy Sunday morning, cold and gray outside. Residents at the Twin Parks North West tower in the Bronx awoke to children and chores — and then the morning twisted in an instant into a blackening nightmare.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: Are You a Fan of ‘School Accounts’ on Social Media?
description: Students are posting photos of their classmates dozing off in class, wearing cute outfits and parking their cars poorly. Are these accounts all in good fun, or do they keep everyone on edge?
content: Have you heard of “sleep accounts” on social media that catch students dozing off in class? Why do you think they are popular right now?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Romancing the Royal Portrait
description: In three new birthday portraits, Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge, gives the fairy tale relevance and a hit of Pinterest inspiration.
content: Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge, the commoner-turned-royal formerly known as Kate Middleton, wife of Prince William, mother of a future king, has turned 40. In honor of the event, three new portraits have been unveiled to the world, to go on display in three locations before becoming part of the permanent collection of London’s National Portrait Gallery, there to remain for posterity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford
title: Noncitizens’ Right to Vote Becomes Law in New York City
description: Starting next year, 800,000 legal permanent residents will be eligible to vote in municipal elections.
content: Mayor Eric Adams, setting aside prior misgivings, allowed a bill to become law on Sunday that would grant more than 800,000 noncitizens the right to vote in municipal elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape
title: Churchill Downs Draws a Hard Line With Bob Baffert
description: Anticipating a lawsuit that would challenge its ban of the Hall of Fame trainer, the track accused Baffert of “inventing excuses.”
content: Bill Carstanjen, the chief executive of Churchill Downs, had a clear message to lawyers for Bob Baffert on Monday: We will see you in court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced and Kellen Browning
title: Take-Two will buy Zynga, in a union of two top game makers.
description: Adding Zynga’s stable of app developers is meant to help Take-Two roll out more smartphone versions of its popular video game titles.
content: The video game publisher Take-Two Interactive agreed on Monday to buy Zynga, a mobile game maker, for more than $11 billion, in a deal that unites the makers of Grand Theft Auto and FarmVille.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Musinguzi Blanshe and Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Uganda Reopens Schools After World’s Longest Covid Shutdown
description: Many countries have closed classrooms on and off, but Uganda had kept more than 10 million students at home since March 2020. Critics say it took a heavy toll.
content: KAMPALA, Uganda — Uganda reopened its schools on Monday after the longest pandemic-prompted shutdown in the world, but educators and others say that the closing has taken a lasting toll, eroding decades of classroom gains in the East African nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus
title: What Is ‘Love Bombing’?
description: Grand romantic gestures in the early days of a relationship could be sweet — or a sign you’re dating a narcissist. Here’s how to tell the difference, according to experts.
content: Imagine you’re at a restaurant one night, and after dinner you decide to order not one but two slices of cheesecake for dessert. Many would say that’s unhealthy — or at least indulgent — but everyone deserves a treat once in a while. Right?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tressie McMillan Cottom
title: We’re All ‘Experts’ Now. That’s Not a Good Thing.
description: Widespread scams and institutional failures force us to rely on only ourselves.
content: Happy New Year!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: The I.R.S. is warning of a messy tax season.
description: The agency, which has been hobbled by paperwork backlogs and short staffing, said tax filers should expect a lower level of service this year.
content: WASHINGTON — The federal tax filing season will run from Jan. 24 to April 18 this year, the Internal Revenue Service said on Monday, warning in its announcement that staffing shortages and paperwork backlogs could make for a messy and frustrating experience for taxpayers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: Haitian Prime Minister Had Close Links With Murder Suspect
description: New evidence suggests the man who took over from Haiti’s murdered president had close links to a prime suspect in the assassination — and that the two stayed in contact even after the crime.
content: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — After Haiti’s president was assassinated and the country slid into turmoil, Ariel Henry became head of the government, responsible for bringing the killers to justice and helping the country heal.
source.name: The New York Times

title: As Its Population Soars to 40, Rum Isle Glimpses a Future in the Mist
description: With four new families recently arriving, the remote and rainy island in the Hebrides is experiencing its version of a population surge, although residents new and old concede living here isn’t easy.
content: ISLE OF RUM, Scotland — No doctors. No restaurants. No churches. And worst of all for some: no pubs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Covid 3.0, Biden 2.0 and Trump Number …
description: The new year is off to an unusual start.
content: Bret Stephens: Happy ’22, Gail. Hope your year is off to a good start. Eager to get your thoughts on Covid 3.0, which nearly every other person I know seems to have.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Key diplomatic talks about Ukraine.
content: Russian and American officials met last night to begin high-stakes negotiations over threats to Ukraine and a widening gulf between Moscow and the West. There was deep pessimism on both sides that a diplomatic solution was within reach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin
title: Breakouts and lockdowns in Chinese cities make a risk-free Olympics look unlikely.
description: Officials are racing to extinguish a spate of coronavirus infections around the country.
content: When China’s leader Xi Jinping inspected the Beijing Winter Olympics venues last week, he laid out his vision for a “green, safe and simple” event.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Jim Jordan Refuses to Cooperate With Jan. 6 Panel
description: The Republican congressman from Ohio, a close ally of former President Donald Trump’s, denounced the House investigation of the Capitol riot as one of the Democrats’ “partisan witch hunts.”
content: WASHINGTON — Representative Jim Jordan, Republican of Ohio, announced on Sunday that he was refusing to cooperate with the House select committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, joining a growing list of allies of former President Donald J. Trump who have adopted a hostile stance toward the panel’s questions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Manchin’s Choice on Build Back Better: Mine Workers or Mine Owners
description: Senator Joe Manchin III is caught between the mine workers’ union, which supports President Biden’s social policy and climate bill, and mine owners in his state who oppose it.
content: WASHINGTON — For years, burly men in camouflage hunting jackets have been a constant presence in the Capitol Hill office of Senator Joe Manchin III, their United Mine Workers logos giving away their mission: to lobby not only for the interests of coal, but also on more personal matters such as pensions, health care and funding to address black lung disease.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: In Mist, Rain and Mud, Island’s Residents Find Their Kind of Paradise
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, January 10, 2022.
content: “We live in a world now where people associate sunny and hot weather with positivity and happiness and rainy and dark as negative. But there is beauty in everything, and I quite enjoy cold, windy and stormy weather.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Pundit Accountability
description: Writers and experts should be transparent about what they got wrong.
content: Jennifer Nuzzo is a health expert who has become nationally prominent during the pandemic. She is the leading epidemiologist for Johns Hopkins University’s much-cited data collection on Covid-19 testing. She is active on Twitter and quoted frequently in the media. She can explain complex ideas in clear terms, and she has often been prophetic about Covid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: Can the West Stop Russia From Invading Ukraine?
description: The United States, its NATO allies and Russia meet this week in a whirlwind of diplomacy aimed at averting the largest military action in Europe since World War II. Here’s a guide to what’s at stake.
content: It feels like a scene from the Cold War.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia Heyward
title: Chicago’s public schools cancel Monday’s classes.
description: The teachers’ work stoppage is extending to a fourth school day, while negotiations with the city go on.
content: Public school students in Chicago woke up Monday facing another day of canceled classes, as a labor stalemate continued between the city and its teachers’ union over in-person instruction and pandemic safety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Burke
title: From Northern Ireland, Dance as a ‘Physical Prayer’
description: Oona Doherty, a rising star in Europe, brings a Belfast-inspired piece to New York. “This is about kinetic trauma,” she says. “This is about you, as well.”
content: “Push!” the choreographer Oona Doherty shouted, as a group of young women sprinted in a circle to a propulsive drumbeat. It was a chilly night at the Gibney dance studios near Union Square, with the windows wide open to improve ventilation, a safety measure in the midst of the Omicron wave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Russia Plays Down Invasion Threat
description: The U.S. called some demands “non-starters.”
content: After nearly eight hours of negotiation in Geneva, Russian and U.S. officials said they would continue discussions, but they remained far from agreement on meeting each other’s security concerns. Here are the latest updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Iman Stevenson
title: A Rising Designer Brings Hip-Hop to Homeware
description: Sean Brown is the creative force behind Curves, a home décor brand inspired by African American pop culture. “I always aim to celebrate Blackness,” he said.
content: The Toronto-based designer Sean Brown made a splash in 2020 with rugs inspired by classic CDs that you might have come across while scrolling through Instagram. In just a few years, Curves, which started with an event at a Toronto gallery, has grown into a contemporary homeware brand that offers products inspired by hip-hop (a color-changing umbrella featuring lyrics from Mobb Deep and Missy Elliott; a grocery tote depicting music video stills), stocked by stores around the globe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: After Its Odds-Defying Run, John Cariani Says Bye to ‘Caroline, or Change’
description: The pandemic shutdown gave the actor time to reconnect with his clarinet, helping him fully realize his character, a lost-in-grief musician.
content: For a little while on Sunday evening, after the final performance of “Caroline, or Change” at Studio 54, the actor John Cariani disappeared from backstage to have his portrait taken upstairs. No one had told the boys, though, and when Cariani reappeared, his young castmates — some of whom had played his son — flocked around, teasing him and hugging him. They were palpably pleased he hadn’t given them the slip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: ‘Encanto’ Soundtrack Ousts Adele From No. 1
description: The album of music from the latest Disney animated film climbs to the top of the Billboard 200 after first arriving in November.
content: The soundtrack to “Encanto,” the new Disney animated film, has reached No. 1 on the Billboard chart, displacing Adele’s “30” after a six-week run at the top.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Top Democrat says the Fed must release more details on its trading scandal.
description: Senator Elizabeth Warren, the Massachusetts Democrat, pressed the central bank to provide more information by next Monday.
content: Senator Elizabeth Warren, Democrat of Massachusetts, asked the Federal Reserve in a letter sent Monday to release more information about a series of financial trades that several top officials made in 2020, when the Fed was actively propping up markets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Ayala
title: As W.N.B.A. Players Call for Expansion, League Says Not Now
description: Many players and fans want bigger rosters and more teams, but the W.N.B.A. said it can’t “expand for expansion’s sake” without the money to support it.
content: On Oct. 17, Lexie Brown became a W.N.B.A champion. She and the Chicago Sky defeated the Phoenix Mercury to win the first title in franchise history. Yet, four months prior, Brown was sitting at home wondering if she would ever find her way back into the league.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Jerome Powell will tell senators that Fed policymakers see high inflation’s toll.
description: Central bankers will act to keep rapid price gains from becoming permanent, Mr. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, will say during a renomination hearing.
content: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair whom President Biden has nominated for a second four-year term, is set to tell senators on Tuesday that central bankers will use their economic tools to keep inflation — which has been high — from becoming entrenched.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: The Woods Are Still Lovely, Dark and Deep, and We Have Promises to Keep
description: For all the problems it can cause, snow is a respite from the speed of the modern world.
content: NASHVILLE — It was 78 degrees here on New Year’s Day, a record high for Nashville, and I broke into a sweat just packing for a weekend on the Cumberland Plateau. “Did you remember to bring your coat?” my husband asked when I got into the car.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: The Fed’s vice chair resigns as questions mount about his early-pandemic trades.
description: Richard Clarida, the vice chair of the Federal Reserve, will leave on Friday, two weeks ahead of schedule. Updated disclosures showed rapid moves out of and back into stocks as the central bank prepared to reassure markets.
content: Richard H. Clarida, the Federal Reserve’s vice chair, announced on Monday that he would resign from his position two weeks earlier than planned. While he did not give a reason, he had faced renewed scrutiny about trades he made in 2020 as the central bank was poised to rescue financial markets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Klay Thompson Returns, as if He Never Left
description: He barked at officials. He launched 3-pointers. He played off the crowd. And he soared for an emphatic dunk.
content: Klay Thompson of the Golden State Warriors has never been known as a leaper. He used to have a running competition with Zaza Pachulia, a former teammate, to see who could finish each season with the most dunks. As more of an earthbound athlete, Thompson knew his dunks were cause for celebration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Robert Durst, Real Estate Scion Convicted as a Killer, Dies at 78
description: He was a suspect in three lurid murders and became a fugitive. In September, he was found guilty in the fatal shooting of a confidante and sentenced to life in prison.
content: Robert A. Durst, the scion of a New York real estate dynasty whose life dissolved in a calamity of suspicions over the unsolved disappearance of his first wife, the execution-style murder of a longtime confidante and the killing and dismemberment of an elderly neighbor, died early Monday as a prisoner in Stockton, Calif. He was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: How Families Can Navigate the I.C.U.
description: A new book offers guidance on how family members can support a critically ill loved one who ends up in the hospital’s intensive care unit.
content: In the last two years, the letters I.C.U. have become almost as familiar to the listening and reading public as PBS and NBC, as intensive care units across the country have been overwhelmed with people suffering from severe Covid-19. Meanwhile, medical personnel continue to struggle to care for patients with serious injuries, diseases or surgical complications who also require critical care.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul and Anemona Hartocollis
title: Lawsuit Says 16 Elite Colleges Are Part of Price-Fixing Cartel
description: The federal lawsuit against Yale, M.I.T. and other colleges is the latest legal action to question admissions practices.
content: A lawsuit filed in federal court on Monday accused 16 of the nation’s leading private universities and colleges of conspiring to reduce the financial aid they award to admitted students through a price-fixing cartel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Fresh Iberico Pork Delivered to Your Door
description: Campo Grande’s new Iberico pork sampler box offers a rib roast along with three cuts of pork steaks.
content: Iberico, the prized pork from Spain’s free-ranging heirloom breeds is best known in its cured state, as ham. But fresh Iberico in the muscle cuts typical in Spain, is delicious roasted, grilled or pan-seared. Campo Grande, an American company that works directly with small farmers in Spain, is a new source for the meat. The founder, Kurt Oriol, who is from Spain, had previously helped create Iberian Pastures, a company that raises Spanish heirloom pigs in Georgia. Campo Grande sells a box of assorted cuts of pork: a hefty four-rib roast, a thick presa from the loin for roasting or grilling, and two prized shoulder sections, pluma and secreto. Each one provides at least four servings of succulent, tender meat, best cooked just shy of medium. The company is also importing aged beef and some seafood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: Aung San Suu Kyi Gets 4 Years for Greeting a Crowd and Having Walkie-Talkies
description: Myanmar’s ousted civilian leader was convicted on three more counts under Covid and telecommunications rules, which her defenders said were politically motivated.
content: Myanmar’s ousted civilian leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, was convicted Monday and sentenced to four years in prison for possessing walkie-talkies in her home and for violating Covid-19 protocols.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes, Michael Crowley and Eric Schmitt
title: Russia Positioning Helicopters, in Possible Sign of Ukraine Plans
description: The step, which could be an indication that planning for an attack continues, comes as the number of Russian troops at the border has remained steady in recent weeks, despite U.S. expectations of a surge.
content: WASHINGTON — The number of Russian troops at Ukraine’s border has remained steady in recent weeks, despite U.S. intelligence predictions of a surge, but American officials say that President Vladimir V. Putin has begun taking steps to move military helicopters into place, a possible sign that planning for an attack continues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez and Alan Yuhas
title: Bob Saget, Comic Who Starred in Sitcom ‘Full House,’ Dies at 65
description: The actor, who had also hosted “America’s Funniest Home Videos,” was found dead in an Orlando hotel room while on tour.
content: Bob Saget, the stand-up comic and actor who was known as Danny Tanner on the long-running sitcom “Full House,” as the host of “America’s Funniest Home Videos” and for his deadpan, ribald stage routines, was found dead on Sunday in Orlando, Fla. He was 65.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Craig Spencer
title: As an E.R. Doctor, I Fear Health Care Collapse More Than Omicron
description: The Omicron wave is different from March 2020, but it’s still serious.
content: As the Omicron tsunami crashes ashore in New York City, the comforting news that this variant generally causes milder disease overlooks the unfolding tragedy happening on the front lines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Must the Shows Go On?
description: Hollywood’s disrupted awards season is as much about box office as it is about self-congratulation.
content: On television, the pandemic is already over. In reality, it continues to wreak havoc on the entertainment industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles V. Bagli
title: Robert Durst’s Death Comes With a Bizarre Legal Twist
description: Mr. Durst’s murder conviction in California could be vacated because he died while an appeal was pending. A murder charge in New York appears to be moot.
content: The bizarre life of Robert A. Durst, the wayward scion of a vast New York real estate dynasty, ended on Monday when he died at 78 in a California hospital while serving a life sentence for murder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: Audie Cornish, the former NPR host, heads to CNN+.
description: The CNN president Jeff Zucker is staffing up as he prepares for a streaming debut in the spring.
content: Audie Cornish, who signed off as a host of NPR’s news program “All Things Considered” on Friday, is heading to CNN’s new streaming service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: In a First, Man Receives a Heart From a Genetically Altered Pig
description: The breakthrough may lead one day to new supplies of animal organs for transplant into human patients.
content: A 57-year-old man with life-threatening heart disease has received a heart from a genetically modified pig, a groundbreaking procedure that offers hope to hundreds of thousands of patients with failing organs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick and Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: A Family of 5 Tried to Flee the 19th Floor. Smoke Overwhelmed Them.
description: The Dukuray family had left Gambia over a decade ago and settled into a top-floor apartment in the Bronx building that burned on Sunday.
content: The Dukuray family had followed the same path as many of their neighbors, leaving the small West African nation of Gambia over a decade ago to join a tight-knit immigrant enclave in the Bronx.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Dunne
title: What We Learned From Week 18 in the N.F.L.
description: Matthew Stafford’s late-game miscues sank the Rams against the 49ers, and the Colts laid an egg against the Jaguars, leaving the door open for the Steelers to sneak into the playoffs.
content: The Los Angeles Rams pushed the chips in on this season. That much was clear when the team traded for Matthew Stafford, just the sixth N.F.L. quarterback to throw for at least 40 touchdowns in multiple seasons, last January.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall, Grace Ashford and Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: 19 Killed in New York City’s Deadliest Fire in Decades
description: Nine children were among those who died when a space heater malfunctioned in a Bronx apartment building, city officials said.
content: Follow live coverage of the Bronx apartment fire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Thomas
title: What If You Could Read a Fashion Label Like a Food Label?
description: Transparency and traceability is all the rage when it comes to clothing, and it is finally reaching the tags on the rack.
content: One of the biggest fashion trends of late 2021 didn’t have to do with color or skirt length or sequins but rather with sustainability. Or, to be specific, the appearance of clothing labels with data that consumers can use to trace the creation of a potential purchase.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: Playoff Fans in the Cold as College Football Plots Its Future
description: Recent huddles among the sport’s leaders have shown how much television drives their thinking.
content: INDIANAPOLIS — Freezing rain had turned the downtown sidewalks here into granite-hard slip-and-slide tracks. A downtown concert stage and beer garden sat vacant, a dance and light drone show was canceled, and getting a restaurant table — even a socially distant one — was no problem at all on Saturday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Petersen
title: We Shot a Moose, Class. There Will Be a Quiz.
description: A small group of Alaskan middle-schoolers get a hands-on lesson in hunting and processing food from the land.
content: NIKISKI, Alaska — Before the sun rose on Nov. 11, 10 students from Nikiski Middle & High School had gathered with their teacher, Jesse Bjorkman, at a gas-station parking lot here in this small community on the Kenai Peninsula — to gear up for a moose hunt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: To Understand the Metaverse, Look to Video Games
description: Xbox head Phil Spencer discusses how the gaming industry is already peeking into the metaverse with avatars, virtual worlds and online economies.
content: When it comes to the metaverse, Phil Spencer could give Mark Zuckerberg a run for his money. The head of Xbox and executive vice president of gaming at Microsoft, Spencer says popular games like Microsoft’s Halo and Minecraft — and competitors like Roblox and Fortnite — are already creating virtual worlds similar to the metaverse. And he says that video games, whose sales have soared during Covid, could offer lessons for the workplaces that have moved online in the pandemic: “We look at these virtual spaces, and some of the things that we’ve learned in video games of people coming together to cooperate together, to achieve tasks.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.4 Million Homes in California
description: A midcentury-modern home in Sacramento, a two-bedroom condominium in Los Angeles and a Cliff May-designed ranch house in Long Beach.
content: This house was designed by John Harvey Carter, an architect who designed more than 400 private and public buildings in the Sacramento area and served as a member of the city’s planning commission. It has been owned by the same family since it was built, and the sellers have updated the bathrooms and the kitchen while maintaining the original layout, which includes midcentury flourishes like a sunken living room and a reflecting pool.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Novak Djokovic’s Fight to Play Tennis Could Be Just Starting
description: The days-long battle to enter Australia to defend his Open title presages headwinds he may face if he attempts to travel the world without being vaccinated for Covid-19.
content: Novak Djokovic has fought through adversity of his own and others’ making for as long as he has been playing tennis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Nearly 5 Years After Grenfell Fire, U.K. Tells Developers to Pay for Upgrades
description: After a deadly high-rise blaze in 2017, countless instances of unsafe building practices came to light. The latest plan to address them expands who will be covered.
content: LONDON — Britain’s housing secretary announced plans on Monday to overhaul the government’s approach to building safety issues across England, saying the financial burden should fall on developers to address lapses in fire safety in hundreds of apartment blocks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: ‘People Need to Be Reminded About Flu’
description: With Covid surging again and vaccine fatigue rising, vaccination rates for influenza are troublingly low, especially among older Americans.
content: Jillian Gibson hasn’t gotten a flu shot in some 25 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Union wins election at a second Buffalo-area Starbucks.
description: A second store could add potency to the economic pressure, such as a work stoppage, that winning a contract often requires.
content: The National Labor Relations Board announced Monday that it had certified a victory for a union at a second Starbucks store in the Buffalo area, where votes were tallied in December but remained inconclusive as the union challenged the ballots of several employees it said did not work at the store.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: 6 New California Laws You Should Know About
description: Changes to the minimum wage, composting rules, police procedures and more.
content: A new year is upon us, and 2022 means not only the arrival of Year 3 of the coronavirus pandemic (yikes), but also the implementation of hundreds of new laws in California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Capri by Way of Keuka Lake
description: Le Moné, a new aperitif with a wine base, brings the sunshine thanks to bright lemon and blue agave.
content: New York’s Finger Lakes may freeze in winter, but the region can also provide the allure of sunny Capri. Le Moné, a new Meyer lemon drink made in Hammondsport, N.Y., has enough bright, citric flavor to cancel winter. It is called an aperitif wine because its base alcohol is wine, from the Finger Lakes region in western New York. Eric Bachli, a former brewmaster at Sixpoint Brewery in Brooklyn, collaborated with Max Nevins, also of Sixpoint Brewery, and Marissa Reiser, a sommelier, to create the aperitif. California brandy adds a kick to the 32 proof drink. Restrained sweetening is provided by organic blue agave syrup from Mexico, and Meyer lemons, mostly from a distillate using the peels, create the lightly bitter citric profile. It’s mellow yet refreshing on the rocks or in a spritz; it finds its calling added to dry gin, martini-style with a twist. It’s now shipped to a handful of states, a list that will expand in coming months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: lingua franca
description: This term has appeared in 16 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William J. Broad
title: How European Royals Once Shared Their Most Important Secrets
description: Recent research highlights the use of letterlocking techniques by Queen Elizabeth, Catherine de’ Medici and Mary Queen of Scots.
content: To safeguard the most important royal correspondence against snoops and spies in the 16th century, writers employed a complicated means of security. They’d fold the letter, then cut a dangling strip, using that as an improvised thread to sew stitches that locked the letter and turned the flat writing paper into its own envelope. To get inside, a spy would have to snip the lock open, an act impossible to go undetected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Carl Bennett, Founder of Caldor Discount Stores, Dies at 101
description: He and his wife, Dorothy, turned a walk-up store in Westchester, N.Y., into a 100-outlet behemoth that reached $1 billion in annual sales.
content: Carl Bennett, who transformed an $8,000 investment in a second-floor “Walk-Up-&-Save” store in Port Chester, N.Y., in 1951 into Caldor, the regional discount powerhouse chain that he sold three decades later for $313 million, died on Dec. 23 at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 101.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Jan. 10, 2022
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Jan. 10, 2022.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Uga X made the trip to Indianapolis and met another famous bulldog, too.
description: Two top dogs in the same place at the same time.
content: The most famous bulldog in Indianapolis these days is Butler Blue IV, the mascot at Butler University.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Symone Sanders, a Top Strategist for Biden and Harris, Is Joining MSNBC
description: Ms. Sanders, 32, will host a weekend show on the cable network, one of the first big programming moves by MSNBC’s president, Rashida Jones.
content: Symone D. Sanders, the former chief spokeswoman for Vice President Kamala Harris, is joining MSNBC as an anchor and will host a new weekend program on the cable channel, the network said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt and Alan Feuer
title: Pence and Jan. 6 Committee Engage in High-Stakes Dance Over Testimony
description: Getting the former vice president to answer questions under oath could be crucial as the House panel focuses on Donald Trump’s responsibility for the Capitol riot.
content: As the House select committee investigating the Jan. 6 assault on the Capitol rushes to gather evidence and conduct interviews, how far it will be able to go in holding former President Donald J. Trump accountable increasingly appears to hinge on one possible witness: former Vice President Mike Pence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu
title: Despite safety measures, space heaters remain a fire risk.
description: Portable space heaters have been linked to around 1,700 residential fires every year.
content: Federal authorities are investigating a devastating Bronx fire that city officials have said was caused by an electric space heater that malfunctioned in an apartment bedroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave and Matthew Futterman
title: Novak Djokovic Can Remain in Australia, Judge Rules
description: Australian officials hinted they may make a new attempt to cancel Djokovic’s visa, even as the tennis champion, freed from detention, returned to the court.
content: SYDNEY, Australia — Novak Djokovic, the Serbian tennis star, moved one step closer to competing for his record 21st Grand Slam title after an Australian judge ordered his release from immigration detention on Monday, the latest turn in a five-day saga over his refusal to be vaccinated for Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: In India, mask wearing is down, even as case numbers rise.
description: Health officials are finding it harder to impose regulations despite signs that Omicron is beginning to take hold.
content: Health officials in India have reported an increasing number of people refusing to wear masks, despite rising case numbers fueled by the Omicron variant, with rule breakers’ excuses including seeing masks as a sign of weakness or as simply unhelpful in preventing infection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango and Max Whittaker
title: ‘Nothing Will Be the Same’: A Prison Town Weighs a Future Without a Prison
description: After a decade of efforts that sharply reduced inmate populations, California is closing prisons. One town at the edge of a valley in remote northeast California whose economy is built on incarceration is waging a legal battle to keep a prison open.
content: SUSANVILLE, Calif. — The Mauldin family loved their house. They bought it during the financial crisis and spent a lot of money to upgrade the tan, farmhouse-style home. New landscaping and fencing so the two kids would have a nice place to play. An entirely new kitchen and new floors. Rows of lilac bushes lining the driveway. But when word came down last spring that a prison in the town of Susanville would close, the family made a decision they never wanted to make: They put their home up for sale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Alexander Smalls Plans a Food Hall for Harlem. But First, Dubai.
description: The chef and restaurateur hopes to open a vast food hall, Alkebulan, in central Harlem, following its debut at Expo 2020 Dubai.
content: In October, an African food hall, Alkebulan, opened as part of Expo 2020 Dubai. It was created by Alexander Smalls, the Harlem chef, restaurateur and performer, with TGP International, a hospitality management company based in London. Originally the plan was to open Alkebulan first in Harlem but the pandemic interfered and then, as Mr. Smalls put it, “Dubai came calling.” With a name that was once that of the African continent and is said to mean “mother of mankind,” the hall has 11 stands created by Mr. Smalls and run by African chefs and restaurateurs, with West African street food, barbecue, dishes inspired by Zanzibar and East African seafood. The lineup includes Mr. Smalls’s own Shoebox Bakery, Chicken Coop and Sweet Ophelia’s, an Afro-Asian wok bar. The Harlem version is back on track to open next year, and then another Alkebulan is set for London. The partners are looking for a two-story location in Central Harlem with more than 20,000 square feet of space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: 4 Operas in 48 Hours: A Critic’s Marathon at the Met
description: Amid the virus surge, the company is performing “Rigoletto,” “Le Nozze di Figaro,” “Tosca” and “La Bohème” in close succession.
content: Even for a critic who attends performances as a way of life, there were more than a few similarities to “Groundhog Day” in seeing four shows over 48 hours at the Metropolitan Opera this weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whet Moser
title: Ukraine, Covid tests, Football: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag
title: Twin Parks North West opened in 1972 as a celebrated experiment in affordable housing.
description: The building, designed by an architectural firm, was among 12 sites in the Bronx intended to reimagine subsidized housing and promote integration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Eric Adams’s First Days: Battling Omicron, Then a Deadly Fire
description: During his first week in office, the mayor focused on keeping schools open. Then on Sunday, he was faced with devastating loss of life in the Bronx.
content: Before he took office as mayor of New York City, Eric Adams repeatedly said that his top priority was to serve as the city’s cheerleader and promote its recovery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: Friend Who Bought Kyle Rittenhouse’s Gun Gets Reduced Charges
description: Dominick Black, a friend of Mr. Rittenhouse, had been accused of two felonies for buying the weapon. In a plea deal with prosecutors, he will pay a fine.
content: CHICAGO — Dominick Black, a friend of Kyle Rittenhouse who faced two felony charges for buying a rifle used by Mr. Rittenhouse, has agreed to plead no contest to lesser charges in a deal announced in a Wisconsin courtroom on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: Google must turn over more documents in a labor case, a judge rules.
description: The latest tranche totals about 200. They are among more than 1,000 that the company, accused of firing union organizers, claimed were protected by attorney-client privilege.
content: Google wrongly claimed attorney-client privilege to protect documents subpoenaed in a National Labor Relations Board case filed by former employees who say the company fired them because of their unionization efforts, a labor judge has ruled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisha Cooper
title: Was There Joy in East Rutherford?
description: Looking for beauty in a meaningless N.F.L. game between the Giants and Washington Football Team, on a wet, cold Sunday afternoon in New Jersey.
content: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — When the Giants (4-13) played the Washington Football Team (7-10) at MetLife Stadium on Sunday, both already having been eliminated from the N.F.L. playoffs, was it possible to find beauty and meaning — or, at least, warmth — in a game with so little at stake?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: Uncovering Mysteries of Female Dolphin Sexual Anatomy
description: A close examination of 11 clitorises from common bottlenose dolphins suggests the female cetaceans experience pleasure during frequent sexual activity.
content: Common bottlenose dolphins have sex frequently — very likely multiple times in a day. Copulation lasts only a few seconds, but social sex, which is used to maintain social bonds, can last much longer, happen more frequently and involve myriad heterosexual and homosexual pairings of dolphins and their body parts. Anything is possible, and, as new research suggests, probably pleasurable for swimmers of both sexes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: The fire was the deadliest in New York City since 1990.
description: An arson at the Happy Land Social Club killed 87 people more than 30 years ago.
content: The Bronx fire that killed 17 people on Sunday was the deadliest fire in New York since 1990, when a fire at a Bronx nightclub left 87 dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: In Zora Neale Hurston’s Essays, the Nonfiction of a Nonconformist
description: “You Don’t Know Us Negroes,” edited by Genevieve West and Henry Louis Gates Jr., is a collection of nonfiction by the author of “Their Eyes Were Watching God.”
content: Zora Neale Hurston’s best-known sentence, judging by its appearance on coffee mugs and refrigerator magnets, is this one: “No, I do not weep at the world — I am too busy sharpening my oyster knife.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: These Boats Are Really Big, but Barcelona Has the Room
description: The city has become a hub for billionaires’ superyachts, banking on the strength of the “blue economy.”
content: BARCELONA, Spain — Launched less than a year ago, the 460-foot-long, eight-deck Solaris is one of the newest of the superyachts that are the floating palaces of the sea. It has a helipad, of course, plus a swimming pool and all the other high-tech amenities required by its Russian billionaire owner, Roman Abramovich.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz and Alan Blinder
title: Push to Expand College Football Playoff Stumbles
description: Eleven of the sport’s top figures have been unable to reach an agreement after months of negotiations, stalling hopes for more teams to be included in the national title race.
content: INDIANAPOLIS — The College Football Playoff’s ambitions for expansion stalled on Monday, when the sport’s leading power brokers proved unable to agree on a plan almost seven months after some of them publicly proposed a 12-team format.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Clay Aiken, Former ‘American Idol’ Star, Announces Run for Congress
description: Mr. Aiken said he was running as a “loud and proud Democrat” for an open House seat in his native North Carolina this year.
content: Clay Aiken, the former “American Idol” contestant, said on Monday that he was running for Congress in North Carolina, in his second attempt to represent the state where he grew up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: The head of New York Public Radio will take charge of Politico.
description: The Washington news organization, under new ownership, names Goli Sheikholeslami as its chief executive.
content: Goli Sheikholeslami, the head of New York Public Radio, will become Politico’s new chief executive, Axel Springer announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annabelle Williams
title: Chris Dickerson, Who Broke Bodybuilding Barriers, Dies at 82
description: Nicknamed “Diamond Calves,” he was the first Black man to win the Mr. America contest. As a gay man, he said, he also felt bigotry over his sexual orientation.
content: Chris Dickerson, who as the first Black man to win the Mr. America contest shook up the musclebound world of bodybuilding and established himself as one of its elite competitors, died on Dec. 23 in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Sydney Harper, Michael Simon Johnson, Stella Tan, Kaitlin Roberts, Luke Vander Ploeg, Liz O. Baylen, Larissa Anderson and Marion Lozano
title: The Rise and Fall of the Golden Globes
description: For eight decades, the awards and the organization behind them  played an outsized role in Hollywood. Here’s what changed.
content: This year’s Golden Globes ceremony was muted. Instead of a celebrity-filled evening, broadcast on NBC, the results were live tweeted from a room in the Beverly Hilton.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor and Christine Chung
title: How to help survivors of the deadly Bronx apartment fire.
description: Several organizations were accepting donations after New York City’s deadliest fire in decades left at least 17 people dead.
content: A fire and choking smoke inside a 120-unit apartment building in the Bronx killed at least 17 people, including eight children, on Sunday and injured more than 60 others. New York City officials said the blaze, which drew roughly 200 firefighters and was among the city’s deadliest in decades, was likely caused by a malfunctioning space heater.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: On Her Way Up: Yankees Tap Woman as Minor League Manager
description: Having served as a hitting coach in the team’s system, Rachel Balkovec will be the first woman to manage a team in affiliated baseball.
content: Rachel Balkovec, a groundbreaking baseball coach, will become the manager of a team in the Yankees’ minor league system, making her the first woman to lead an affiliated professional baseball squad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: The Endless Pop Shimmers of the Weeknd
description: “Dawn FM” extends and reimagines Abel Tesfaye’s fixation on perfect pop that he’s been chasing since the mid-2010s.
content: There’s not a moment to breathe on the new album by the Weeknd, “Dawn FM” — no spaces for resolution and calm, no indications of a world outside of its borders. An uninterrupted set of iridescent megapop anthems blended like a D.J. mix, it is, as with so many things that he has made in the last decade, an all-or-nothing proposition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna P. Kambhampaty
title: After Nearly 50 Years, a Beloved East Village Indian Boutique Is Closing
description: Dress Shoppe II, an Indian fabric and clothing shop in Manhattan, will shut its doors at the end of January.
content: Walking into Dress Shoppe II is like walking into an emporium of color and cloth. The shelves are overflowing with hand-embroidered fabrics and saris, the racks are tightly packed with kurtas and salwar suits, and even the ceilings are covered in intricate tapestries. Below the main floor of the shop, there are two storage floors packed with piles of additional product. All of it needs to go by Jan. 31.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Jackson
title: On the Slopes With a Pro Skier
description: Follow along with a skiier who climbs up the hill before heading back down.
content: Follow along with a skiier who climbs up the hill before heading back down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: A Sci-Fi Visionary Thinks Greed Might Be the Thing That Saves Us
description: “Am I dipping into the spiritual realm and the infinite game of life? Damn right I am.”
content: “Am I dipping into the spiritual realm and the infinite game of life? Damn right I am.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: 52 Places for a Changed World
description: The 2022 list highlights places around the globe where travelers can be part of the solution.

title: How Much Do You Know About Uganda?
description: Can you find Uganda on a map? What else do you know about this African country with about 45 million people?

title: Dosas Are Only the Beginning
description: Venison stew, stir-fried snails and other less-heralded dishes of South Indian cuisine are showcased at Semma.
content: Venison stew, stir-fried snails and other less-heralded dishes of South Indian cuisine are showcased at Semma.

title: What You Get for $1.4 Million in California
description: A midcentury-modern home in Sacramento, a two-bedroom condominium in Los Angeles and a Cliff May-designed ranch house in Long Beach.
content: A midcentury-modern home in Sacramento, a two-bedroom condominium in Los Angeles and a Cliff May-designed ranch house in Long Beach.

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: NATO Warns Russia of High Price for Aggression Against Ukraine
description: Jens Stoltenberg, NATO’s secretary general, said Western allies would hold a series of meetings with Russian diplomats this week amid Russian military threats in eastern Ukraine.
content: Jens Stoltenberg, NATO’s secretary general, said Western allies would hold a series of meetings with Russian diplomats this week amid Russian military threats in eastern Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Storyful and The New York Times
title: Train Crashes Into Downed Plane Seconds After Pilot Is Rescued
description: Videos captured the moment Los Angeles police officers pulled a pilot from the wreckage of a plane just before a train slammed into it.
content: Videos captured the moment Los Angeles police officers pulled a pilot from the wreckage of a plane just before a train slammed into it.

title: Talking to Voters From Both Parties
description: Readers are upset that Republicans in one of the focus groups still believe that the election was stolen. Also: Vaccine mandates; marriage and divorce.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook Right Now
description: New recipes for vegetarian bean and cheese burritos, vegan avocado-ranch dressing and more.
content: Good morning. It takes a special kind of optimist to believe that the microwave bean and cheese burrito at the gas station might actually be good. And that’s me six times a year, even if I know deep down that it won’t satisfy, and that I’ll regret my decision to eat it by the third bite. The thrill is in the possibility: What if this one is great?
source.name: The New York Times
